data.title: Center of Excellence for Structural Durability
data.text:
Concrete durability

Condition assessment and health monitoring of structures

Accelerated bridge construction and demolition (ABCD)

Prefabricated bridge elements and systems (PBES)

Nondestructive testing

Structural Resilience

On-going projects

Capacity Prediction of Repaired and Unrepaired Bridge Beams with Deteriorated Ends

Funding Agency: The Michigan Department of Transportation

PI/Co-PI: Upul Attanayake, Ph.D., P.E.; Yufeng Hu, Ph.D., P.E.

Duration: October 2022 – September 2024

Bridge inspection engineers and consultants submit requests for action (RFAs) due to safety concerns associated with steel girder and prestressed concrete (PSC) beam end conditions. Region bridge engineers review RFAs and bring forward to the Bridge RFA Coordination Committee (BRFACC) for deliberations. This project focuses on developing guidelines and tools for bridge inspection engineers, region bridge engineers, and the other members of the BRFACC to help them streamline the RFA submission and evaluation process. This will help overcome programming and resource allocation challenges while ensuring public safety and avoiding potentially unnecessary restrictions on the motoring public. These tools and guidelines will help the Load Rating Unit (LRU) load rate deteriorated and repaired beam ends.

Operational Baseline and Structural Health Monitoring for the 2nd Avenue Network Arch Bridge

Funding Agency: The Michigan Department of Transportation

PI: Upul Attanayake, Ph.D., P.E.

Duration: January 2022 –May 2024

A skewed, unbraced network tied-arch bridge was constructed to carry the 2nd Avenue over I-94. This 265 ft long, 96.5 ft wide structure carries vehicular traffic, bicycles, and pedestrians in separate dedicated lanes. The unique structural configuration and the use of innovative accelerated bridge construction (ABC) technique made this one of the most significant projects in bridge engineering. The bridge skeleton, consisting of trapezoidal steel arch ribs, tie girders, end diaphragms, and steel floor beams was assembled in a staging area near the bridge site. In implementing ABC, the bridge skeleton was moved into alignment using self-propelled modular transporters (SPMTs) during a 7-day closure of I-94. Following the SPMT move, including lifting and sliding activities, and the placement of the skeleton on permanent bearings, the remaining construction activities were completed.

The ultimate goals of this project are to establish (i) the final state of stress at the end of the 2nd Avenue over I-94 bridge construction, (ii) the operational baseline by conducting a static live load test, (iii) stress envelopes for the safe operation of the structure, and (iv) a functional monitoring system and necessary tools for data-driven maintenance decision-making.

For official, current semester course information, consult the WMU catalog.

Undergraduate courses

CCE 3080—Civil Engineering Materials

This course is 3.0 credit hours with 2.0 lecture hours and 3.0 lab hours weekly.

The course focuses on the study of constituents of materials used in civil and construction engineering, physical and mechanical properties of materials, and laboratory and field methods for the evaluation of materials.

ACI Field Technician Grade I Certification: We have established a process in collaboration with the Michigan Concrete Association (MCA) for WMU CCE students to obtain the American Concrete Institute (ACI) Concrete Field Testing Technician - Grade I certification at the end of the course.

CCE 3360—Soil Mechanics

This course is 3.0 credit hours with 2.0 lecture hours and 3.0 lab hours weekly.

The course focuses on the study of the physical properties of soil and the behavior of soil masses subjected to various types of forces. Further, this course will focus on origin of soil and its grain size distribution, ability to drain water, compressibility, shear strength, and load-bearing capacity. During this course, students will learn application of laws of mechanics and hydraulics to engineering problems dealing with different soil types.

This course is 3.0 credit hours with 2.0 lecture hours and 3.0 lab hours weekly.

CCE 4561—Foundation and Earth Retaining Structure Design

This course covers the analysis, design, and construction aspects of shallow and deep foundations and retaining structures. The main objective is to enable students to select, analyze, and design an appropriate foundation and/or an earth retaining structure for a given scenario.

This course is 3.0 credit hours.

Graduate courses

CCE 5460—Design of Timber Structures

Structural behavior of wood under loads; application of current timber design codes; design of structural components and systems in wood; mechanical properties of wood fasteners and connections.

This course is 3.0 credit hours.

CCE 5460—Design of Timber Structures

Structural behavior of wood under loads; application of current timber design codes; design of structural components and systems in wood; mechanical properties of wood fasteners and connections.

This course is 3.0 credit hours.

CCE 6470—Bridge Engineering

The course focuses on analysis, design, and rating of bridges as per the AASHTO Specifications/Guidelines. Simplified analysis procedures as well as use of software tools will be covered.

This course is 3.0 credit hours.

CCE 6480—Finite Element Applications

The course focuses on the study of finite element applications to common engineering problems including linear static, heat transfer, flow through porous medium, seepage, resistivity, etc. During the course, ABAQUS is used as the analysis tool.

This course is 3.0 credit hours.

CCE 6510—Structural Systems and Assessment

The course focuses on (1) behavior of structural systems made of concrete, steel, and precast components or a combination thereof and (2) structural condition assessment by visual inspection, nondestructive evaluation (NDE) techniques, and destructive testing techniques or a combination thereof. Students will be given an opportunity to conduct investigations using some NDE techniques.

This course is 3.0 credit hours.
